Note: I got all reputation stars.

I played this on the 3DS almost a decade ago. When I saw it was on a huge sale on Steam, I decided to re-buy it and see if it was as good as I remember. Well, it's a great game, but not quite as good as I thought it was. I'd recommend buying Steamworld Heist 2 over this, since that's only a very loose sequel and is generally a better game.

Good:
- The ricochet gameplay is really fun.
- A great soundtrack with both the instrumental music and songs from Steam Powered Giraffe being excellent.

Neutral:
- The story's whatever. It's a wacky setting, but the core plot is weak. That's fine, the plot is in the background for this game. If you're coming from SH2 then the worldbuilding is a fair bit weaker here, with a bit less dialogue from NPCs and enemies.
- The class system isn't particularly exciting. A character's ability going from +2 damage to +3 for their final level just feels underwhelming.

Bad:
- On most difficulties, you lose half your currency for losing a mission. This is annoying and means that losing a mission means you leave it in a worse state than you entered. Likewise, defeated crewmates don't get any XP. It feels a bit punishing since completing a mission barely gets you less resources than intended, which can compound if you don't go back and grind.

185588397.review:
[h1]Roboter im Weltall [/h1]

Nachdem ich mir den [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2396240/SteamWorld_Heist_II/]zweiten Teil[/url] bereits kostenlos dank des Kuratorenprogramms zur Gemüte führen durfte, habe ich mir mal den Vorgänger geholt. Erfahren wir einmal, ob er genau so viel Spaß macht.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
In „SteamWorld Heist“ ändert sich das 2D Buddelspiel der Vorgänger zu einem rundenbasierten Taktikableger. Wir schicken eine kleinen Trupp an Kämpfern mit verschiedenen Kämpfern in kleine Missionen und im besten Fall kommen auch genau so viele Kämpfer wieder aus der Mission raus. Jede Figur hat pro Runde zwei Aktionen zur Verfügung und verfügt einzigartige Fähigkeiten. Im ersten Teil gibt es noch kein Multi-Class Prinzip wie im [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2396240/SteamWorld_Heist_II/]zweiten Teil[/url]. Stattdessen haben die Bots zwar Klassen, entwickeln jedoch mit einem Level-Up einfach linear ihre eigenen Fähigkeiten. Dies schränkt gerade neu rekrutierte Bots erst einmal ein, aber man kann sich ja sehr frei entscheiden, welche Missionen man erledigen möchte oder auch welche Bots man immer mitleveln möchte. Persönlich mag ich es, wenn meine Leute ja ein ähnliches Level haben und relativ ausgeglichen sind.  Wir zielen übrigens selber und bekommen je nach Waffenwahl manchmal eine Hilfslinie. Das Knifflige daran? Die Leute sind etwas unruhig und viele Waffen haben keine Ziellinie, die wie beim Scharfschützen extrem hilfreich sein kann.
Kurzgesagt ist “Steamworld Heist” also ein Sidescroller [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/200510/XCOM_Enemy_Unknown/]XCOM[/url], in dem wir selber kalkulieren müssen, ob der Schuss ins Ziel geht oder nicht.  Der Aufbau der Level und die Art der Feinde werden dabei in jedem Level neu generiert. Also kann auch ein bereits erledigter Auftrag beim zweiten Mal ganz anders laufen. Das Spiel ist ohnehin darauf ausgelegt, dass man viele Level öfters spielt, da man eine gute Sternebewertung oder aber zusätzliche Beute und Erfahrung haben möchte. Trotzdem ist es mit ca. 15 Spielstunden nur halb so lang wie sein [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2396240/SteamWorld_Heist_II/]Nachfolger[/url].
Zum Spielen kann ich übrigens einen Controller empfehlen, mit dem man sich angenehm zurücklehnen kann.

[b]Story[/b]
Nachdem die Erde aufgrund bestimmter Ereignisse nicht mehr so ganz existiert, treiben sich die Bots auf verschiedenen „Scherben“ des Planeten herum und natürlich auch im Weltall. Piper Faraday will als Schmugglerin zwar überwiegend ihre Ruhe, allerdings bekommt sie diese Ruhe dank der Schrotter und der Marine nicht. Also beschließt die Dame auf eigene Faust mal so richtig durchzuräumen. Auf dem Weg kommen wir einer größeren Geschichte auf die Spur und unterhalten uns mit unseren rekrutierten Mitgliedern, die ihren ganz eigenen Charme mit einbringen. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3407461059
Allerdings darf man hier jetzt keine große Geschichte erwarten, die voller Plottwists ist. Stattdessen haben wir unsere eher oberflächlichen Helden und bekämpfen oberflächliche Feinde. Zum Verständnis hilft es, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/571310/SteamWorld_Dig_2/]SteamWorld Dig 2[/url] gespielt zu haben. Aber notwendig ist es sicherlich nicht. 

[b]Grafik/Sound[/b]
Die Grafik ist konsequent bunt gehalten. Ich mag den rostigen Stil und insbesondere die Machart der Charaktere. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3407463065
Man kann das Spiel problemlos auf Deutsch spielen. Allerdings gibt es dann doch manchmal Fehler bei den Texten, wodurch man den Sinn nicht mehr versteht. Ich nehme an, man hat da wirklich jemand Englischsprachigen das Spiel ins Deutsche übersetzen lassen. 

[b]DLCs[/b]
Die kosmetischen drei Hüte der Hatbox sind kostenlos verfügbar. Allerdings muss man die sich im Steam Shop manuell holen. Die andere Hatbox enthält ebenfalls nur Hüte, ist allerdings kostenpflichtig. Um man die braucht…Am Interessantesten dürfte das DLC „The Outsider“ sein, in dem wir ein neues Mitglied für unsere Crew bekommen, der eine Verbindung zum Vorgänger [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/571310/SteamWorld_Dig_2/]Steamworld Dig 2[/url] mitbringt. Diese Figur hat nicht nur im Kampf interessante Fähigkeiten, sondern bringt auch ein paar neue Missionen mit.

[b]Fazit[/b]
Genau wie der [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2396240/SteamWorld_Heist_II/]zweiten Teil[/url] hat mir auch der erste Teil sehr gut gefallen. Die Spiele ähneln sich zwar, aber dennoch kann ich beide klar empfehlen. Dieses Spiel fällt hier noch etwas flacher in den Spielmechaniken wie Klassen aus. Auch haben wir noch keine Oberwelt zu bereisen. Man könnte also sagen, der erste Teil ist simpler, aber auch das ist erfrischend. Leider wird es keinen dritten Teil geben, aber ich kann die „Steamworld“-Spiele, die sehr vielfältig sind, trotzdem sehr empfehlen. 


Rundenstrategie mag ich ja sehr. Für mehr davon und noch viel mehr Reviews in anderen Bereichen schau doch mal in [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Drakeschool] meiner Steamgruppe[/url] oder der [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ger_steam] German Steam Community[/url] vorbei!

184561187.review:
[h2] Painfully horrible strategy game [/h2]

Let's get to the point, since this is going to be a long review/rant.
For a game whose selling point seems to be an XCOM-like game without RNG, since you hit enemies by manually aiming, every single other mechanic in Heist is entirely at the whims of chance.
I spent the first 3 hours of this game unaware of this fact, and judging by some of the positive reviews... seems some went the entire game without realizing this.
Before I get into that, I should bring up that only YOUR attacks aren't affected by RNG, enemies are less lucky.
Expect AI to pull off the most insane ricocheting trickshots one moment, and then miss a shot just a few tiles away by blatantly aiming at the barrel right below you.
Now, what else is RNG?

[b] Level design [/b]
Every single mission in this game is not actually fully designed by a human, which isn't promising for a strategy game where every shot is crucial.
That doesn't have to be something bad by itself, but you will see in a moment how all of this mess comes together in the worst way possible.
The way maps work is that they designed simple rooms, who are then randomly stitched together.
Wouldn't be as much of an issue if it wasn't for the fact that the enemies are also completely random, both their positions and what type of enemy they are.
Speaking of positions, another randomized aspect are the barricades that spawn, objects you can receive cover from.
So with enemy type, placement and barricades being randomized, a mission can swing wildly from being a walk in the park to straight up impossible.
The way the stats work in this game is that enemies have about as much HP as you do, in some cases more, but they usually only deal like half the damage that you do.
Of course, the game makes up for this by having a lot more enemies than you have characters, sometimes even for a single room.
Still with the right weapon, you're gonna be able to ideally oneshot most enemies, while your opponents can't do the same to you.
This means that offense is the best defense... which is exactly why making all these placements random is a truly devastatingly awful choice.
You could therefore enter a room with enemies near the start, easy to reach and maybe not even all of them being behind a cover.
Alternatively, you could enter that room with enemies being at the opposite side of the room, at a higher and hard to reach position, protected by a ton of barricades.
Suddenly, something that could have been an easy two turn clear with very minimal damage taken, could result in a full-on party wipe and game over.
Obviously speaking with experience here.
A map can generate some of the most evil things with the assets it has... or it just doesn't.
There's no middle ground with its difficulty.
I haven't faced a single casualty and then beat a mission, it's either a flawless victory or a game over, nothing between that.
Still, maybe there would be ways to win with all these odds stacked against you, if you could approach the mission in any way you want... which is often not possible, leading me to the last big point.

[b] Reinforcements [/b]
Reinforcement spam, it's real.
They mainly show up through the alarm mechanic, which, despite my very apparent hate for how RNG is handled in this game, might be the actual mechanic that drags this game down to the deepest pits of hell.
Don't worry though, RNG is also involved with reinforcements.
When an alarm is active, a countdown appears, ticking down every turn until it reaches zero.
Every time the alarm reaches zero, the threat level is increased, initially causing reinforcements to start spawning, with each subsequent threat level increasing the amount.
The reinforcements are also endless and will never stop.
Alarms can be triggered halfway through certain missions with multiple objectives.
However, more often than not, these alarms are present in missions from turn 1.
Progress-based reinforcements seem fine, but I'm not a fan of turn 1 stuff.
It leaves basically no way to play a mission the way you want, and you gotta rush like hell.
Even in that case, it could still be fine for missions where all of this is taken into account, but turn 1 alarms start appearing like every second to third mission.
I can understand why you wouldn't want to make a strategy game where the player has infinite time to do whatever they want, but I'm more of a believer in rewarding players for being fast, rather than punishing them for being slow.
Still, either option can work, but this game handles it in the worst way.
I also sincerely doubt that the devs gave it that much thought, since half of the missions don't have an alarm and you can be as slow as you want there.
Of course, the main problem still remains that none of the levels are actually designed by a person, but an algorithm, meaning that a map can actually never be designed around reinforcements, making it seem like they flipped a coin to determine which ones will have alarms.
Also, how silly of me to not mention that reinforcements will be able to act on the same turn that they spawn as well.
Now, take a guess how all of this comes together with the rest of the RNG mechanics to create a truly unforgettable experience... unforgettable in the bad way, I mean.
The multiple reinforcement gates are placed randomly, but you can't prepare yourself for that in advance either, because where they come out of is also random, with nothing giving their arrival away... and then of course they also get their turn immediately.
The worst possible decision at very step.
Remove the infinite aspect, suddenly it could become bearable.
Remove the ambush aspect, suddenly you're a lot safer.
Remove the random aspect, suddenly you can prepare yourself for where they'll be.
Individually still not good, but putting it all together makes me doubt that s single dev has actually playtested this abomination.
Although I don't think it's possible to playtest a game you didn't even fully design, since they let the robots take the wheel.

[b] Conclusion [/b]
Procedurally generated content is utilized in roguelikes for a reason.
They require an endless number of runs that need to feel different, with a hopefully good core gameplay that keeps it fun and consistent.
This is a linear game with missions and a clear end, a strategy game where every move matters.
It has no reason to involve generated content.
What does it say about you when you can't be bothered to design proper levels for it?
It's not a fun quirky gimmick, it ruined a potentially great game.
Hell, I didn't even mention there being a loot box mechanic, because it's also something I wasn't initially aware of, because why would the items you receive in this game be determined by RNG?
Well... it makes a lot of sense once you know that EVERYTHING ELSE ALSO IS!
It's disappointing how easily Heist could have been something special, because outside of the gameplay, it's super charming and has great character designs... and frankly, it's also fun when the RNG goddess doesn't make you suffer.
Makes sense, because the other major SteamWorld series, SteamWorld Dig, is good.
The first game wasn't too great, but a unique breath of fresh air, while its sequel improved on every aspect, I strongly recommend it.
Heist is so broken at its core that I no longer trust these devs enough to even try out its recent sequel.
In fact, their obsession with procedural generation makes me wary of ever giving a game of theirs another chance.

In conclusion, stay as far away from Heist as possible.
I don't understand why this game has received so many positive reviews, but maybe playing this on the easiest difficulty or grinding by replaying old missions (another thing I didn't know about initially) makes it tolerable.
Hardly an excuse for creating a fundamentally unfair and terrible game, however.
Maybe the devs handing the keys over to robots is their defense, though.
Which is... very ironic for the world they've created.

184549568.review:
Steamworld: Heist is a vastly underappreciated title. For anyone interested in turn-based games this is a wonderful entry, offering a fairly simple 2-D interface cutting down on a lot of the tactical overhead most games demand. But grizzled veterans of turn-based games will find novelty here, too, with the physics portion of combat and in manually aiming to get that key ricochet.

Set in the "Steamworld" universe you play a PIRATE CAPTAIN running from the law. You gain levels, crew, and - most importantly - hats along your journey to defeat the dastardly empire-analogy. Between combat encounters you'll discover story, talk to citizens of the world, shop for new gear, etc. It's light but all the better for it.

Adequately paced at probably a a 15-20 hour campaign (depending on whether you want to 3-star every level or not) it both provides a nice helping of adventure but doesn't overstay its welcome. Perhaps on the easier side for those who are into this genre, don't be afraid to up the difficulty.

As I know it's a sticking point with this genre, there are some timed missions but if I recall they are mostly of the "rage timer" variety (increasingly more spawns) rather than hard ends, though I think there is one or two "hard stop" timed missions in there. Regardless, not overly bothersome.

Steamworld Heist is simply full of fun, charm, wit, and hats. There's really nothing more a pirate captain could need.

Однако оказалось, что помимо вышеуказанного игра вываливает на тебя ТОННУ врагов, что в первые часа три от прохождения вызывало недоумение, дискомфорт, а порой и фрустрацию. Честно говоря проблема даже не в этом, а в том что в описании сложности не сказано об этом ни слова. Скорее всего, это чисто придирки, но все же. Если нравится пошаговые игры, то Вам обязательно стоит заценить эту игру.
